steps.title: Typical steps in a foreclosure auction
steps.subtitle: Every auction is different – these steps help you get started. In case of doubt, please consult specialised legal or tax advisors.

items.title: 1. Screen suitable properties
items.description: Filter by region, property type and budget to find relevant auctions.

items.title: 2. Check appraisal & documents
items.description: Carefully read the court appraisal, land register extracts and all available documents.

items.title: 3. Clarify your financing
items.description: Talk to your bank or financing partner early on to know your bidding limit.

items.title: 4. Note the auction date
items.description: Save the date and ask the responsible court about procedure, deadlines and formalities.

items.title: 5. Get professional advice
items.description: For legal, tax or structural questions, you should involve qualified experts.

faq.title: Frequently asked questions
faq.subtitle: These answers provide an initial overview and do not replace professional legal advice.

items.question: Is the auction price always a bargain?
items.answer: Not necessarily. The final price depends on demand, condition and risks of the property. Renovation backlog, legal issues or contamination have to be considered in your calculation.

items.question: Can I visit the property beforehand?
items.answer: Viewings are not always possible but often can be arranged via the appraiser or other parties. Details can be found in the official documents.

items.question: How does financing work?
items.answer: Many banks finance foreclosure auctions but often require equity and a fast payout after the auction. Clarify your financing before you attend the auction.

items.question: Which risks should I keep in mind?
items.answer: Potential risks include unclear occupancy, existing tenancy agreements, refurbishment needs or hidden defects. In case of doubt, involve legal and technical experts.
